Award.AwardTitle: Ensemble Docking Interrogates Structural Determinants of Ligand-Protein Interactions
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award, the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Chemistry Division at NSF is supporting the work of Dr. Jens Meiler of Vanderbilt university on an international collaborative effort to develop a new and potentially generally useful ensemble docking method for the RosettaLigand molecular modeling program. The German team inthis collaboration will be led by Drs. Annette Beck-Sickinger and Torsten Schoenefeld at U. Leipzig and will be supported by the DFG (Deutsche Forschungsgemeinschaft), and represents the experimental side of the collaboration. The ensemble docking approach to be taken involves simultaneous docking of multiple ligands while considering experimental SAR (Structure-Activity Relationships) as part of the scoring function. The collaborative team has selected the family of G-protein-coupled 7-(helix) transmembrane receptors (GPCRs) and ligand candidates as a platform upon which to develop this methodology. The German partnering team will take a natural product-inspired approach to ligand development/binding assessment for these receptors.

Given the importance of protein-membrane receptor interactions across chemical biology, the proposed research aims at developing in silico methodology with potentially broad applicability to the community. Indeed success here and the possibility for disseminating the envisioned RosettaEnsembleDock module to the community would constitute arguably the most important scientific broader impact of this collaborative effort. The importance of GPCRs in signal transduction in biology cannot be overstated and therefore the model system upon which this computational algorithm is being built is also of considerable significance. The project will provide for interdisciplinary and international student training and exchange, and for the synergistic interaction of experimental protein-ligand binding team in Germany with a computational modeling/algorithm development team in the United States.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goals of this project to develop an algorithm ‘ROSETTALIGANDENSEMBLE’ that docks an ensemble of small molecules with known affinities/activities into a comparative model of the membrane protein. The algorithm will optimize Spearman’s rank correlation between predicted binding affinities and biological data. The algorithm will dock flexible small molecules into flexible membrane proteins to account for inaccuracies in the comparative model and conformational changes upon interaction. We will apply the method to the identification of structural determinants required for agonistic and inverse agonistic ligand properties at G-protein coupled receptors. This proposal is a joint project between researchers at Vanderbilt and Leipzig Universities in response to a special joint funding opportunity between NSF-CHE and the DFG. The project strengthens scientific and cultural relations between U.S. and Germany through exchange of faculty, graduate students, and undergraduate students.

We completed a first manuscript on the ROSETTALIGANDENSEMBLE algorithm. Modifications to the ROSETTA source code were completed to enable ROSETTALIGANDENSEMBLE. A benchmark set of proteins with a ligand co-crystal structure and a series of ligands with known activities was tested. Optimization of the ROSETTALIGANDENSEMBLE algorithm and associated parameters is complete. In parallel, we worked with our collaborators in Leipzig University to construct comparative models of several G-protein coupled receptors that we started to apply the algorithm to. To coordinate this collaboration, the PI of the grant Jens Meiler traveled to Germany in Fall 2015 and Fall 2017 to work on this collaboration. We published several manuscripts showing the utility of ROSETTALIGANDENSEMBLE for developing allosteric modulators of the Y4 receptor. Further, we are finalizing a manuscript disseminating new best-practices protocols for GPCR modeling and ligand docking with Rosetta.

 


Last Modified: 12/30/2018
Modified by: Jens Meiler
